title: The Multiplication Principle of Counting states that if event A can occur in $$n$$ ways, and after A happens, event B can occur in $$m$$ ways, then the total number of ways event A and event B can occur (in sequence) is simply the product of the number of ways each event can occur.

To apply the Multiplication Principle, consider that event A can occur in $$n$$ ways, and event B can happen in $$m$$ ways after A. The total number of outcomes where both events happen is just the multiplication of the two possibilities. So, what does this mean in terms of $$n$$ and $$m$$?
